async_info.video_title: A new front in Syria's war - BBC News
async_info.video_description:
The civil war in Syria looks set to enter a new and even more dangerous phase, with government forces on the move to help Kurdish fighters under attack from Turkey. Turkish forces crossed into Syria last week. The Turkish government regards the Kurdish fighters as terrorists, and wants to occupy a buffer zone reaching 20 miles into Syria. The Kurds have now turned to Syria's President Assad for help. And today Syrian government forces entered several towns just south of the border - setting up a potentially dangerous confrontation with Turkey.
Huw Edwards presents the latest from Syria on tonight's News at Ten, with contributions from International correspondent Orla Guerin, Middle-East correspondent Quentin Sommerville and Middle-East editor Jeremy Bowen.
Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

President Donald Trump has replaced American exceptionalism with ‚ÄúAmerica First.‚Äù Now the United States is not distinct from other countries. We are a nation like any other, says Trump, and ‚Äúit is the right of all nations to put their own interests first.‚Äù In his 2016 foreign policy address, Trump called it ‚Äúa dangerous idea‚Äù to believe ‚Äúthat we could make western democracies out of countries that had no experience or interests in becoming a western democracy.‚Äù

Why, then, is Washington spending $717 billion in fiscal year 2019 to maintain vast armies, fleets, and air armadas around the world? Not for defense, of America, anyway. It is to protect allies, assert influence, remake failed societies, dictate behavior, promote values, and more. All of these may have some value, though rarely as much as asserted. And none have much to do with protecting America‚Äôs territory, people, constitutional system, and prosperity.

comment_content.original_script:
If Syria is a "regime" then why can't the BBC be honest and describe the monarchic, medieval, gulf theocracies, as theocratic, absolutist regimes? "Syrian Arab Army" is the title of Syria's armed forces. Syrians are fighting to prevent their country being overrun by Turkish/Saudi/US/UK backed terrorists, or to prevent the country's disintegration. They did not join to be Assad's paramilitaries, they are the Army of Syria. Another regular omission, is the fact that the Syrian Army have done the heavy lifting in defeating ISIS/Daesh. The kurds fought ISIS/Daesh in the north of the country, but it was US air power that "liberated" Kobani and Raqqa, by levelling both cities. The kurds have since occupied everything east of the Euphrates, in the hope of creating a marxist utopian state, on Arab lands, funded by stolen oil. No discussion is permitted by the state broadcaster, about Syria's territorial integrity, after all it's an ancient country, why should it be broken up to create yet another US client state?


The BBC were also loathed to show that Assad still has support among Arabs, in fictional "Rojava", but they didn't really go into depth as to the reasons why Arabs resent the kurdish occupation. Much more focus was given to the family in Turkey, which claimed that even though Erdogan is invading Syria, it's Assad who is keeping them from going home? They were "happy" when the Turkish army invaded, and they hoped to go home "when the kurds left" - so they expected that the Turks would take over all of northern Syria? They wouldn't even live in kurdish controlled areas, otherwise they would have already returned to Syria. This is contradictory. The BBC support the kurds, but they are so keen to highlight Assad's villainy, that they interview a family who want to return to Syrian lands, which Turkey have ethnically cleansed (and plan to annex)? Every report by the BBC on Syria, also assumes that the US redeployment, is a "win" for Russia and Iran?. What is more apparent is the tense standoff that will ensue between Syrian forces, and Turkey, which as Jeremy admitted, would draw NATO/Russia into a hot war - so how is that a "win" for Russia?
